body:
Ah, I think this error code was being silently masked until e2bf91452a263ff8babb3e5e153a2d2c7b4b3719 was fixed.

Can you try this which stops rclone trying to create the bucket in the first place?

https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.52.0-021-gcb7d5520-fix-4297-s3-mkdir-beta/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

Thanks for testing :-)

I've merged this to master now which means it will be in [the latest beta](https://beta.rclone.org) in 15-30 mins and released in v1.52.1 which will be out in a few days hopefully.

issue.title: Rclone Copy command - Access denied

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is your current rclone version (output from `rclone version`)?
v1.50


#### What problem are you are trying to solve?

I'm trying to upload a txt file from aws ec2 instance to s3 bucket
with the help of **rclone copy filename remote:bucketname**.  I get 403 forbidden error access denied when I'm uploading a text file to s3 bucket. And i tried to add checksum to the above command **--ignore-checksum** it's giving me the same error.

Note 
I am able to upload the txt file with aws commands  **aws s3 cp  txtfile  buckname --sse aws:kms**

#### How do you think rclone should be changed to solve that?

Need aws s3 Proper documentation on how to upload file with encryption and without encryption.

issue.title: rclone copy S3 Access Denied with minimal PutObject ACL

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
<!--

Welcome :-) We understand you are having a problem with rclone; we want to help you with that!

If you've just got a question or aren't sure if you've found a bug then please use the rclone forum:

    https://forum.rclone.org/

instead of filing an issue for a quick response.

If you think you might have found a bug, please can you try to replicate it with the latest beta?

    https://beta.rclone.org/
    
If you can still replicate it with the latest beta, then please fill in the info below which makes our lives much easier.  A log with -vv will make our day :-)

Thank you

The Rclone Developers

-->

#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?

rclone will not copy files to a Amazon S3 bucket with only the `PutObject` authorization granted to the IAM role attached to an EC2 instance.

#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)

`rclone v1.52.2`

#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (eg Windows 7, 64 bit)

`os/arch: windows/amd64` : Windows 10 64 bits

####  Which cloud storage system are you using? (eg Google Drive)

`S3`

#### The command you were trying to run (eg `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

`rclone.exe copy file.txt s3bucket:redactedbucketname/somefolder/file.txt --no-check-dest --no-traverse --retries 1`

#### A log from the command with the `-vv` flag (eg output from `rclone -vv copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

```
2020/07/20 08:57:49 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.52.2" starting with parameters ["rclone.exe" "copy" "file.txt" "s3bucket:redactedbucketname/somefolder/file.txt" "-vv" "--no-check-dest" "--dump" "headers" "--no-traverse" "--retries" "1"]

2020/07/20 08:57:49 DEBUG : You have specified to dump information. Please be noted that the Accept-Encoding as shown may not be correct in the request and the response may not show Content-Encoding if the go standard libraries auto gzip encoding was in effect.         status code: 403, request id: [REDACTED], host id: [REDACTED]

        status code: 403, request id: [REDACTED], host id: [REDACTED]
2020/07/20 08:57:49 INFO  :
Transferred:             0 / 0 Bytes, -, 0 Bytes/s, ETA -
Errors:                 1 (retrying may help)

2020/07/20 08:57:49 DEBUG : 4 go routines active
2020/07/20 08:57:49 Failed to copy: AccessDenied: Access Denied
        status code: 403, request id: [REDACTED], host id: [REDACTED]
```

Here is the bucket access policy :
```
{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Principal": {
                "AWS": "arn:aws:iam::redactedaccountnumber:role/REDACTEDIAMROLE"
            },
            "Action": "s3:PutObject",
            "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::redactedbucketname/*"
        }
    ]
}
```

The equivalent `aws s3 cp file.txt s3://redactedbucketname/somefolder/file.txt` works fine.

The rclone config section is as follows : 
```
[s3bucket]
type = s3
provider = AWS
env_auth = true
region = us-east-2
```

Regards

body:
@shamil I've had to adjust this fix as it contained an incorrect assumption. This breaks the fix as-is.

However if you try [the latest beta](https://beta.rclone.org) with the --s3-assume-bucket-exists you should find it works fine for you :crossed_fingers:
Why does `rclone`  not assume that a bucket exists on default? Such behaviour is highly misleading especially if one does not use common S3 provider.
Rclone will create the bucket for you (just like it creates directories for you) - that is why it doesn't assume the bucket exists.
